DOC.HEAD: Plants Run 24 Hours To Squeeze Freeze-Damaged Citrus
With PM-Frozen Profits, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Florida's 33 citrus processing plants are pushing their operations to the limit to squeeze frost-damaged oranges before they have a chance to rot. Truckloads of oranges are flooding plants that are running non-stop to process the fruit damaged during a two-day Christmas freeze. Industry officials fear several days of 70-degree weather would cause the damaged fruit to decay and fall from trees if not picked and processed quickly enough. At Tropicana Products Inc., the nation's largest citrus processor, maximum plant capacity is 36 million oranges a day, which translates into 1 million gallons of juice. All of Tropicana's 400-plus fruit-hauling trailers have been mobilized to race the clock, said Tropicana Products Inc. President Robert Soran. ``We'll be open 24 hours per day, seven days a week during the salvage process,'' said Steve Caruso, assistant general manager at Citrus World, a juice processing plant in Lake Wales that produces about 400,000 gallons of fresh juice a day. The Juice Bowl plant in Lakeland also is running non-stop indefinitely. Gov. Bob Martinez lifted highway weight restrictions on trucks so citrus growers can move crops faster. And growers have pressed all migrant farm workers into service to help harvest the fruit from groves hit hard when the overnight temperature plunged as low as the high teens last Sunday and Monday. The final freeze-damage toll won't be known for some time, but Soran said that based on recent estimates, Florida may be able to produce 100 million boxes of oranges this season, down from an anticipated 130 million boxes. A damage estimate is due Jan. 11, said Ernie Neff, a spokesman for Florida Citrus Mutual, which represents citrus growers. Florida and Brazil produce 81 percent of the world's oranges, almost entirely for juice, and Soran said a recent increase in Brazilian production means that the overall supply this year may change very little. Juice made from a blend of U.S. and imported oranges may not fluctuate widely in price at current supply levels, said Soran. However, shoppers may pay more for juices made only from Florida oranges, such as Tropicana's Pure Premium and Minute Maid's Premium Choice, he said.
